title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Robotics and Automated Systems


Mobile Robot Vehicles



Instructor: Aykut Satici, Ph.D. 
 

Mechanical and Biomedical Engineering 
Electrical and Computer Engineering 
Boise State University, Boise, ID, USA


Topics: 

Wheeled Mobile Robots

Car-like mobile robots
Differentially-steered vehicle
Omnidirectional vehicle

Flying robots

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Car-like mobile robots



A commonly used model for the low-speed behavior of a four-wheeled car-like vehicle is the kinematic bicycle model.
The velocity of each wheel is in the plane of the wheel and the wheel rools without slipping sideways: B𝐯=(v,0). {^B}\bm{v} = (v, 0). 
The configuration of the vehicle is represented by the generalized coordinates 𝐪=(x,y,θ)∈𝒞=ℝ2×𝕊1\bm{q} = (x, y, \theta) \in \mathcal{C} = \mathbb{R}^2 \times \mathbb{S}^1.
The dashed lines show the direction along which the wheels cannot move; these lines of no motion intersect at the instantenous center of rotation (ICR).
The angular velocity is θ̇=vRB, \dot{\theta} = \frac{v}{R_B},  and by simple geometry the turning radius is RB=LtanγR_B = \frac{L}{\tan \gamma}, where LL is the length of the vehicle or wheel base.








Bicycle model of a car


The car is shown in light gray and the bicycle approximation is dark gray. The steering wheel angle is γ\gamma and the velocity of the back wheel in the xx-direction, is vv. The two wheel axes are extended as dashed lines and intersect at the Instantaneous Center of Rotation (ICR) and the distance from the ICR to the back and front wheels is RBR_B and RFR_F, respectively.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Car-like mobile robots



For a fixed steering wheel angle, the car moves along a circular arc.
The velocity of the robot in the world frame is (vcosθ,vsinθ)(v \cos{\theta}, v \sin{\theta}) so the equations of motion are

ẋ=vcosθ,ẏ=vsinθ,θ̇=vLtanγ.
\begin{aligned}
\dot{x} &= v \cos{\theta}, \\
\dot{y} &= v \sin{\theta}, \\
\dot{\theta} &= \frac{v}{L} \tan{\gamma}.
\end{aligned}




Characteristics of a car-like vehicle



When v=0v=0 then θ̇=0\dot{\theta} = 0; i.e., it is not possible to change the vehicle’s orientation when it is stationary.
In the world-coordinate frame, the velocity must satisfy an algebraic equality: ẏcosθ−ẋsinθ≡0, \dot{y}\cos{\theta} - \dot{x}\sin{\theta} \equiv 0,  called a nonholonomic constraint. This equation cannot be integrated to form a holonomic constraint, i.e., a relationship between xx, yy, and θ\theta.











Bicycle model of a car


The car is shown in light gray and the bicycle approximation is dark gray. The steering wheel angle is γ\gamma and the velocity of the back wheel in the xx-direction, is vv. The two wheel axes are extended as dashed lines and intersect at the Instantaneous Center of Rotation (ICR) and the distance from the ICR to the back and front wheels is RBR_B and RFR_F, respectively.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Differentially-steered vehicle



Differential steering steers by independently controlling the speed of the wheels on each side of the vehicle – if the speeds are not equal the vehicle will turn.
The vehicle’s velocity is by definition vv in the vehicle’s xx-direction, and zero in the yy-direction since the wheel’s cannot slip sideways: B𝐯=(v,0).
{^B}\bm{v} = (v, 0). 
The configuration of the vehicle is represented by the generalized coordinates 𝐪=(x,y,θ)∈𝒞=ℝ2×𝕊1\bm{q} = (x, y, \theta) \in \mathcal{C} = \mathbb{R}^2 \times \mathbb{S}^1.
The vehicle follows a curved path centered on ICR.
The left-hand wheels move at a speed of vLv_L along an arc with a radius RLR_L while the right-hand wheels move at a speed of vRv_R along an arc with a radius of RRR_R. The angular velocity is θ̇=vLRL=vRRR=vR−vLW,
\dot{\theta} = \frac{v_L}{R_L} = \frac{v_R}{R_R} = \frac{v_R - v_L}{W},
 since RR=RL+WR_R = R_L + W, with WW denoting the wheel separation.








Differential drive robot


The robot is shown in light gray and the unicycle approximation in dark gray. The vehicle follows a path around the ICP and the distance from the ICR to the left and right wheels is RLR_L and RRR_R, respectively. We can use the alternative body frame {B′}\left\{B^\prime\right\} for trajectory tracking control.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Differentially-steered vehicle



The equations of motion are therefore ẋ=vcosθ,ẏ=vsinθ,θ̇=vΔW,
\begin{aligned}
\dot{x} &= v \cos{\theta}, \\
\dot{y} &= v \sin{\theta}, \\
\dot{\theta} &= \frac{v_\Delta}{W},
\end{aligned}
 where v=12(vR+vL)v = \frac{1}{2}\left(v_R+v_L\right) and vΔ=vR−vLv_\Delta = v_R - v_L are the average and differential velocities, respectively.
For a desired speed vv and turn rate θ̇\dot{\theta} we can solve for vRv_R and vLv_L. This kinematic model is often called the unicycle model.
Similar to the car-like vehicle, this model has a nonholonomic constraint as well: ẏcosθ−ẋsinθ=0. \dot{y} \cos{\theta} - \dot{x} \sin{\theta} = 0. 
If we move the vehicle’s reference frame to {B′}\left\{B^\prime\right\} and ignore orientation, we can rewrite the EoM as (ẋẏ)=[cosθ−asinθsinθacosθ](vω).
\begin{pmatrix} \dot{x} \\ \dot{y} \end{pmatrix} = 
\begin{bmatrix} \cos{\theta} & -a \sin{\theta} \\ \sin{\theta} & a \cos{\theta}
\end{bmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} v \\ \omega \end{pmatrix}.
 (To be solved for desired ẋ\dot{x} and ẏ\dot{y}.)








Differential drive robot


The robot is shown in light gray and the unicycle approximation in dark gray. The vehicle follows a path around the ICP and the distance from the ICR to the left and right wheels is RLR_L and RRR_R, respectively. We can use the alternative body frame {B′}\left\{B^\prime\right\} for trajectory tracking control.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Omnidirectional vehicle



Omnidirectional wheels remove the nonholonomic constraint, simplifying control algorithms.
Such ‘’Swedish’’ wheels comprises a number of rollers set around a circumference of the wheel with their axes at an angle of α\alpha relative to the axle of the wheel.
The rollers have a barrel shape so only one point on the roller is in contact with the ground at any time.
Rotation of the wheel will cause a forward velocity of Rω𝐱WR\omega \bm{x}_W where RR is the wheel radius.
Because the roller is free to roll in the direction indicated by the green line, normal to the roller’s axis, there is potentially arbitrary velocity in that direction.
Resolve a desired velocity 𝐯\bm{v} into two components, one parallel to 𝐱W\bm{x}_W and one parallel to the rolling direction 𝐯=vW𝐱W⏟driven+vr(cosα𝐱W+sinα𝐲W)⏟rolling=(vW+vrcosα)𝐱W+vrsinα𝐲W,
\begin{aligned}
\bm{v} &= \underbrace{v_W\bm{x}_W}_{\text{driven}} + \underbrace{v_r\left(
\cos{\alpha} \bm{x}_W + \sin{\alpha}\bm{y}_W\right)}_{\text{rolling}} \\ 
&= \left( v_W + v_r \cos{\alpha}\right)\bm{x}_W + v_r \sin{\alpha} \bm{y}_W,
\end{aligned}

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
text:
Omnidirectional vehicle


 
 

Here vWv_W is the speed due to wheel rotation and vrv_r is the rolling speed.
Hence the required wheel rotation rate is ω=vWR\omega = \frac{v_W}{R}.
A single mecanum wheel does not allow any control in the rolling direction, but for three or more mecanum wheels, suitably arranged, the motion in the rolling direction of any one wheel will be driven by the other wheels.
The four wheel contact points indicated by the gray dots have coordinate vectors B𝐩i{^B}\bm{p}_i. For a desired body velocity B𝐯B{^B}\bm{v}_B and angular rate Bω{^B}\omega the velocity at each wheel contact point is B𝐯i=B𝐯B+Bω𝐳B×B𝐩i. {^B}\bm{v}_i = {^B}\bm{v}_B + {^B}\omega \bm{z}_B \times {^B}\bm{p}_i.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
section: Flying robots or unmanned aerial vehicles
text:
Flying robots or unmanned aerial vehicles



UAVs are becoming increasingly common and span a huge range of size and shapes.
Flying robots have 66-dof with configuration 𝐪∈𝒞=𝐒𝐄(3)\bm{q} \in \mathcal{C} = \bm{SE}(3).
We use a dynamic rather than a kinematic model.
The rotors are driven by electric motors, powered by electronic speed controllers.
The rotor speed is ϖi\varpi_i and the thrust is an upward vector Ti=bϖi2,i=1,2,3,4, T_i = b \varpi_i^2, \; \; i = 1, 2, 3, 4,  in the vehicle’s negative zz-direction.
The translational dynamics of the vehicle in world coordinates is given by Newton’s second law m𝐯̇=(00mg)−0𝐑B(00T)−B𝐯, m \dot{\bm{v}} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ m g \end{pmatrix} - {^0}\bm{R}_B 
\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ T \end{pmatrix} - B \bm{v},
 where 𝐯\bm{v} is the velocity of the CoM in the world frame, gg is the gravitational acceleration, mm is the total mass, BB is the aerodynamic friction and T=∑iTiT = \sum_i T_i is the total upward thrust.











Quadrotor with four rotors, their thrust vectors and directions of rotation. Blue rotors rotate ccw while red rotors rotate cw.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
section: Flying robots or unmanned aerial vehicles
text:
Flying robots or unmanned aerial vehicles



Pairwise differences in rotor thrusts cause the vehicle to rotate. The rolling torque is generated by the moments τx=d(T4−T2)=db(ϖ42−ϖ22), \tau_x = d(T_4 - T_2) = db(\varpi_4^2 - 
\varpi_2^2),  where dd is the distance from the rotor axis to the center of mass.
Similarly, the pitching torque is τy=db(ϖ12−ϖ32). \tau_y = db (\varpi_1^2 - \varpi_3^2). 
The torque applied to each propeller by the motor is opposed by aerodynamic drag Qi=kϖi2. Q_i = k \varpi_i^2. 
This torque exerts a reaction torque on the airframe which acts to rotate the airframe about the propeller shaft in the opposite direction of rotation τz=Q1−Q2+Q3−Q4=k(ϖ12+ϖ32−ϖ22−ϖ42). \tau_z = Q_1 - Q_2 + Q_3 - Q_4 = k \left( \varpi_1^2 + \varpi_3^2 - \varpi_2^2 - \varpi_4^2 \right). 

That is, a yaw torque can be created simply by appropriate coordinated control of all four rotor speeds.










Quadrotor with four rotors, their thrust vectors and directions of rotation. Blue rotors rotate ccw while red rotors rotate cw.

title: 04_mobile_robot_vehicles
section: Flying robots or unmanned aerial vehicles
